title: Cookies
paragraph1: A cookie is a small piece of data that's stored on your computer, tablet, or phone when you visit a website. Most websites need cookies to work properly.
howAreCookiesUsedHeading1: How cookies are used in this service
howAreCookiesUsed-item1: measure how you use the service so it can be improved
howAreCookiesUsed-item2: remember the notifications you've seen so that you're not shown them again
howAreCookiesUsed-item3: temporarily store the answers you give
howAreCookiesUsedParagraph2: Find out more about how to manage cookies.
websiteUsageCookiesHeading1: Cookies used to measure website usage
websiteUsageCookiesParagraph1: We use Google Analytics software to collect information about how you use this service. We do this to help make sure the service is meeting the needs of its users and to help us make improvements, for example improving site search.
websiteUsageCookies-item2: how long you spend on each page
websiteUsageCookies-item3: how you got to the service
websiteUsageCookies-item4: what you click on while you're visiting the service
websiteUsageCookiesParagraph3: We allow Google to use or share our analytics data. You can find out more about how Google use this information in their privacy policy.
websiteUsageCookiesParagraph4: You can opt out of Google Analytics if you do not want Google to have access to your information.
websiteUsageCookiesParagraph5: Google Analytics sets the following cookies:
googleAnalyticsCookiePurpose1: This helps us count how many people visit the service by tracking if you've visited before
googleAnalyticsCookiePurpose2: Manages the rate at which page view requests are made
introMessageCookiesHeading1: Cookies used to turn our introductory message off
introMessageCookiesParagraph1: You may see a welcome message when you first visit the service. We'll store a cookie so that your computer knows not to show this message again.
introMessageCookiePurpose1: Saves a message to let us know that you've seen our cookie message
sessionCookiesHeading1: Cookies used to store the answers you've given during your visit (known as a ‘session')
sessionCookiesParagraph1: Session cookies are stored on your computer as you travel through a website, and let the website know what you've seen and done so far. These are temporary cookies and are automatically deleted a short while after you leave the website.
sessionCookiePurpose1: Carries details of your current session
identityCookiesHeading1: Cookies used to identify you when you come back to the service
identityCookiesParagraph1: We use authentication cookies to identify you when you return to the service.
googleAnalyticsAllowParagraph: Allow cookies that measure website use?
performanceCookiesParagraph1: We use Dynatrace Software Intelligence Platform to provide an Application Performance Monitoring Service to collect information about how you use HMCTS services. We do this to monitor HM Courts and Tribunals (HMCTS) services in order to resolve issues within our services as well as collect data on how our services can be improved. HMCTS stores information about:
performanceCookiesParagraph2: Information is presented within the Application Performance Monitoring service for the purposes detailed above. We do not use or share the information for any other purpose. We do not allow Dynatrace to use or share the information for any other purposes.
performanceCookiePurpose1: Tracks a visit across multiple requests
performanceCookiePurpose2: Measures server latency for performance monitoring
performanceCookiePurpose3: Required to identify proper endpoints for beacon transmission; includes session ID for correlation
performanceAllowParagraph: Allow cookies that measure website application performance monitoring?
securityCookiesHeading1: Cookies used to make the service more secure
securityCookiesParagraph1: We set cookies which prevent attackers from modifying the contents of the other cookies we set. This makes the service more secure and protects your personal information.
securityCookiePurpose2: Identifies you to the service and secures your authentication
